subject: Re: [junit] Re: Any plans to revamp junit?
msgSnippet: ... I admit that, in the case of the classloader fix, the JUnit leaders are being unnecessarily slow. Let me see whether I can do something about that. How
messageBody:
Bill de h√ìra wrote:

> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > Again, I think that's already true. Look at the number of extensions
> > there are out there. Just because they're not in JUnit's contrib/
> > directory doesn't make them any less contributions to JUnit.
>
> No, it means there's no apparent way to get them committed. Scott
> Sterling has been sitting on a classloader fix for heaven knows how
> long. Calling working around the fact that Junit is inactive
> "contributions" to Junit is quite bizarre.

I admit that, in the case of the classloader fix, the JUnit leaders are
being unnecessarily slow. Let me see whether I can do something about that.

How many such fixes are there, though, really? There's the classloader
fix, and the string compares fix, and other than that, everything else
is merely an extension, isn't it? (I'm talking about DbUnit, HtmlUnit,
HttpUnit, XMLUnit, ...)

> I'd direct you to Ant as an example of an open source project that
> accepts contributions; a project by the way that probably has more
> users that Junit but is at least being actively improved and worked on.

Agreed. Ant is also huge and complicated, compared to JUnit.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
